newsitem.title: UK: NWE straight-run offer up after trade at $108 cif.
newsitem.headline: NWE straight-run offer up after trade at $108 cif.

text.p: European low sulphur straight-run got a shot in the arm on Monday after a cargo was said to have fetched $108 cif a tonne, leaving the last seller increasing his asking price.

A Scandinavian refiner, one of only two sellers with prompt 0.5 to 0.7 pct material, said it sold its cargo to a British refiner at $108 cif -- which he said was the equivalent of $98/$99 fob given the high freight rate.
Other traders cited this number although one believed the price seemed a "bit rich".
The deal allowed the second seller to bid up his asking price to $102 a tonne, compared with Friday's $100/$101, which was also an increase of $1 from a day earlier.
Bids were heard to be in the high nineties.
"He's the only seller now with a cargo, so he can charge that price," one trader said.
Sellers have recently increased their asking price in line with gains by crude.
For better quality material, bids rose a little, traders said.
One seller of 0.4 percent straigh run said his asking price was steady at $103/$104 a tonne, adding he reeived two bids at $102.
Traders said that some buying interest was coming in from the United States, but that the high freight cost which has to be factored into bids was delaying deals.
